text:
Hello! I’ve added a post in the HubSpot Ideas for HubSpot to prioritize a better dev/staging experience, please upvote if you think its a good idea!
<https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/HubSpot-Ideas/Staging-Environment-Development-Version/idi-p/737119>

Thanks for sharing this, <@UCDEM8T63>! A heads up to other folks - this is exactly how we want this channel to be used :slightly_smiling_face: To share your Community Board idea for upvotes.

Please post specific questions in the channels most closely fitting the topic at hand. Thanks!

<@UQNEXHW14>

Personally I would prefer that HubSpot (at least for the CMS platform) moved away from upvotes only and also started looking at what just makes sense and eases the workflow of HS CMS.

Here’s an example:

The LINK field type does not feature a Title text input. A HS developer even recently stated that they have known for 3 years but that he didn’t know why it wasn’t sorted.

If i suggested this as an idea (which I have) there’s NO way it would get much interest in the upvote system. Also, many of the top ideas date back to 2017.

It’s just a poor way of prioritise what makes sense to develop honestly
If something makes sense to people and is obviously a good idea then people will upvote it, does that make sense? This in turn helps the development teams prioritize work.
No because the IDEAS section is very poorly visited by devs in my experience and basing decisions solely on what’s popular doesn’t get simple, but necessary, features developed

If something is so necessary and it affect a lot of people then a lot of people will upvote the idea. Example: <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/HubSpot-Ideas/Adding-Notes-via-Workflows/idi-p/429215|adding notes via workflows>. This is a simple and very necessary thing for most companies. Look at that it has 269 upvotes

That’s a false positive Carter.

Ever since it was first mentioned that the LINK field is missing a title input people have worked around it by adding an additional text field.

This fixes the issue, but wouldn’t you agree that having a link field without a title option is cumbersome? Having to create a text field every single time you need it?
I have plenty of issues like that, that would never make it on the vote system but would still make every day development more of a breeze than currently
still talking about CMS platform btw

Why waste dev time on something that has a clear (and simple) workaround. I would much rather have the HubSpot devs work on important features that the community wants rather than things with workarounds
Because it makes HS look stupid and it’s annoying. How is this not obvious?

How are you suppose to gauge necessity without an upvote system? How about the impact to user? Does this impact 10 people or a 100 people? Without people upvoting and saying yes this hurts me how are you supposed to gauge these types of things? Very interested in how your proposed system would work
Because some things just make sense. It isn’t rocket science to cut down on annoying constraints
Upvotes systems being one of those things that just make sense
It really doesn’t if it means HS won’t ever fix simple things that makes development less time consuming and less annoying
Also the CMS platform IDEAS section really lacks visitors and contributors. Dead space honestly
Top ideas still from 2017

You could take the approach of getting really close with the dev team. Just tell them your ideas directly, most of the time they'll say you should put that on the forum (because it's probably not a needed thing or just a bad idea) so that they can gauge the necessity of it, or they'll say that's a great idea let me go have one of my devs work on it.
It will also give you appreciate for the amount of things they work on
And how much development time they have to spare for ideas without any backing

Trust me, I have provided my feedback to everyone I could. From AM to support etc. Nothing ever happens and the fact that HS is aware that something as simple as a title field has been missing for more than 3 years provides no hope
Am I expecting them to do everything I point out? Of course not. But I am not the only one who are wondering why these small things aren’t getting fixed

Also please understand that my critique isn’t just sobbing away. I like HS CMS and I want it to succeed badly - over the likes of Wordpress etc.

But if these constant headaches and workarounds aren’t addressed, it won’t be a truly serious contender. The excessive HTML bloat and poor performance issues, lack of control etc. are major concerns for us and our clients

100% I also would like to see HubSpot succeed, but I think the best way to get ideas implemented is the forum which allows user to say this is really important and this isn't really important. Also keep in mind that HubSpot has different development teams so it's not like just because we can associate contacts to contacts now (a CRM related idea) we won't be able to make changes to the CMS at the same time.
Just for clarification: I see you responding to a lot of questions and offer a lot of help (which is nice). Are you affiliated or hired by HubSpot as an external dev?
Nope just a ~guy~ nerd that likes HubSpot
aha ok. Well kudos to you for being so helpful
100% and thanks for sharing how you feel, these types of things lead to conversations and conversations lead to change

We’ve had 3 or 4 AMs in our time since March, and I have suggested to all of them that certain tier CMS customers can get in contact directly with a dev for support / help / assistance.

They all took note of that wish and mentioned they were looking into something of the sort. I’m hoping it will work out in the future

Thanks for this feedback, all. I should point out that the ideas forum is just one source of feedback we use for internal prioritization. I can’t speak to the specifics mentioned in this thread, but there are many factors considered in prioritizing changes and fixes. Our community voice is a very important factor, but there are more nuanced factors to consider as well. But we are always listening and truly appreciate your feedback.
